theText: the ACT flowing from federal and territory
title: Notices

speaker: Mr Richard Ev Ans To Move:
title: Notices

speaker: In His Column That At A Recent Graduation
theText: Mr ABBOTT to present a bill for an act to
title: Notices

speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
theText: I thank my comradeamend the Maritime College Act 1978, andWednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2503 Wednesday, 19 March 1997 1997 Second Reading Debate resumed from 27 February, on motion by Mr Sharp: That the bill be now read a second time. before the Main Committee brings into effect a measure that was announced in last year's budget. It has the effect of transferring the DIFF loan liabilities from EFIC to the government's national interest account and for the consequent payment to the Commonwealth of a portion$40 million-of EFIC's reserves. This bill means that the Commonwealth will assume contingent liabilities of some $1.7 billion in respect of the DIFF loans. The removal of DIFF loans from EFIC's account removes the difficulties which EFIC has faced through concentration of exposure on the fairly narrow range of countries assisted through DIFF. The opposition does not oppose the legislation. In itself it is non-controversial. However, I point out that the DIFF scheme and the potential for loans under it have been far from noncontroversial. I remind the committee of the circumstance we got ourselves into earlier this year when, unilaterally, the government announced the ending of the DIFF scheme. We remember the embarrassment that was caused to the nation and, specifically, to the Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer) in his telling the parliament that not one country had complained to him about the abolition of the scheme. It was shown, in a very short space of time, that it was true that not one had, but that many had. The minister was forced to come into the parliament and indicate that he had misled it. of the code of conduct of the Prime Minister( Mr Howard), a code of conduct which has been honoured in the breach, not in the application, because this was not the first time there had been scant regard paid to it. The only circumstances in which people are ever ultimately required to honour it is when they are forced to-when they are caught out. The decision of the government, and of the foreign minister in particular, embarrassing as it was for him, was also a very significant setback for a lot of Australian companies which had come to rely on the DIFF scheme. At the time, the minister said that every formal offer for DIFF would be honoured. However, that formal offer only covered seven projects worth some $186 million. In addition to that formal offer, there were 50 other projects which were worth $1 billion which were effectively scuttled because they had received letters of advice to proceed, but not the technicality of the formal offer. The circumstances of this were that this scheme had been in existence over a long period of time-
title: Notices

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl) Took The Chair At 10 A.m.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Crean (Hotham) (10.00 A.m.)
theText: The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Bill
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Price
theText: Very serious.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Crean
theText: One would have thought it was serious and, in fact, a direct contravention
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Price
theText: It used to have bipartisan support.2504 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 the election campaign to maintain it. No doubt it was one of the promises that hit the fence because it was not a core promise. However, the government went to the election saying that the DIFF scheme would be retained. Not only is this scheme important for our bilateral relationships, but it has also been an important driving force for industry development because it has been through this scheme that our heavy engineering industry has actually positioned itself into export markets. Think back a decade ago. At that time, heavy engineering in this cGuntry did very little by way of exports. The difficulty is that it is very hard to get into export markets, particularly in developing countries where what you have to do is compete against other companies bidding for projects where their governments are prepared to back them. Essentially, the backing for those companies comes in the form of either assistance with soft loans through the aid budget or else through a cushioning of the impact, a lessening of the risk. There is risk associated with these things, sovereign risk, but there is also risk in the sense that there is a fairly long lead time before you get payment for the completion of the product. The nature of the DIFF scheme was an essential part not just of our aid program but also it was a sensible use of aid, the leverage of government money, to assist Australian investment, Australian manufactures, Australian expertise and Australian services being exported. This heavy engineering sector has seen a huge growth in exports due in no small measure to the fact that many of the companies were able to rely on the DIFF scheme. There were 52 projects in the DIFF pipeline before the foreign minister created this mess. There were 52 projects but they involved something in the order of 600 Australian companies. There is a multiplier effect in terms of the companies that can be brought into the network. That is what we talk about when we say we shou-ld use the leverage of government assistance, assistance which both parties agreed to, and assistance which is important for the countries to where it is directed. Why can we not have it both ways? Why can we not at the same time say we are prepared to give you that assistance, we are prepared to assist you in your development projects but, provided our own contractors, our own businesses are up to the mark, then they should be able to use this assistance and get themselves into the marketplace? They could be the most efficient producers in the world, they could have the best expertise in the world, but without this assistance they would not be competing on a level playing field. They would have to compete in circumstances where the companies against which they have to bid have the backing of their governments. The point that we are making here is that whilst this technical change in terms of the transfer of the DIFF loan liabilities from EPIC to the government national interest account is taking place, we want to take the opportunity to urge the government to rethink its position on this scheme. It is not the only scheme being changed that has hit Australian manufacturers. The export market development grants scheme, which is being debated in the other chamber, is also a scheme which the government promised would be maintained at the last election but, whilst it is being maintained, it has been heavily slashed. It is very interesting to note these simple facts. Over the last decade, Australia's manufacturing exports have been our fastest growing sector. They now represent 31 per cent of our exports. They are a bigger export earner now than agriculture and they will outpace minerals in the early part of the next decade. The manufacturing sector is not the poor relation
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Crean
theText: Not only did it have bipartisan support, but there was a commitment duringWednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2505 any longer of industry sectors or of potential export earners in this country. However, the simple fact remains that whilst we have seen huge growth in manufactures as a proportion of our exports, still today only 13 per cent of our manufacturers export. So what we have is a huge growth in exports, a marketplace out there into which Australia can position itself. But the assistance is not sufficiently based to encourage more exporters to come into the game and that is why we need export schemes. We need assistance to get us into the export market. That is where the growth in world trade is. It is where our expertise has the capacity to position us but it cannot do it on its own. Australia did have to embrace the notion of reducing its protection levels. Protection is the wrong way to go about trade policy and expanding export opportunities; protection is about stopping imports. Australia has to be about growing its exports. It is too small a domestic market to find the critical mass here alone. But it has the potential to position itself with that critical mass in the global economy and, in particular, in the Asian region. But at the same time as reducing our protection levels we have to have a strategy for positioning our industries for a post-tariff environment. It is not good enough to strip away the protection without also underpinning the support mechanisms to get us into the export markets. It is very interesting, looking at that growth in exports of those manufactures that I have talked about before, that the group that has grown the fastest and the strongest is the group called elaborately transformed manufactures, or ETMs-if you like, the high value-added end of the marketplace. Within that group of ETMs, the areas that have grown the fastest, just to name a few, include automobiles, clothing and textile, food processing, information technology and telecommunications equipment. I name them not because they have been the fastest growers in export values per year-at least 20 per cent per annum growth in all of those sectors-but because they are all sectors that have had some form of assistance. Pharmaceuticals is another group. We are looking at the automobile plan and not the tariff level. It is true that Labor significantly reduced tariffs across the board. It treated automobiles and textiles as a separate category but nevertheless reduced tariff levels, and they are still on their way down to 15 per cent. The reason for the growth in automobiles has not been that we have reduced tariffs but that we have had an export facilitation scheme in place. It is because we have deliberately encouraged and given incentives to these companies not just to produce for a domestic market but also to get out there and flog the things into the world market. And it is not just whole cars, it is the componentry industry. It is the positioning of Australia, because of its expertise, to get into the global market for car componentry. A great example of this is at a place in Adelaide called Henderson Springs, where the Labor party launched its car plan a couple of weeks ago. I see the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) smiling knowingly about this establishment. I hope that she has been down there to visit. If she has not, we will arrange an invitation for her, just as we are arranging one for Neil Andrew, who is about correcting his position and stance on tariffs in the Adelaide Advertiser. The member for Port Adelaide( Mr Sawford) is also very interested to hear about this. Alexander Downer and Ian McLachlan, who cannot spell his name-he spelt it Mac in a letter he sent off to the Adelaide Advertiser-say that they cannot state a position on the car tariff because it would be breaching the solidarity of the cabinet. That did not stop Ministers Hill and Vanstone. They have come out and declared their hand. I wonder who is breaching 2506 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 confidence. I wonder who has got the courage to stand up for Adelaide and stand up for the automobile industry in that place. We know what the position of the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) is. There he was, over at Canberra's most exclusive club the other night, with the minister for industry-and we know where he is at the moment: checking the stock exchanges of the world. Perhaps he is at Stoke Lodge in London. We see that a few on your side of politics are actually vacating for more lofty fields overseas. But the minister forseat. The honourable member for Lowe on a point of order. nothing to do with car tariffs. Could you please ask the member to return to the bill? honourable member for Hotham, I encourage him to stay within the bill, as he has very generally done, but also to refer to members and ministers by their correct titles. to point to the position that this bill, whilst technically correct, is part of a much broader issue that we want the government to focus on. It is not good enough to bury this bill in the Main Committee because it is non-controversial, without understanding the context from which it comes. The context from which it comes is a slate of measures that the government has taken, which is driving our manufacturing base backwards and is restricting our capacity to get into export markets; and DIFF is one of those schemes. To give an example, in relation to the automotive industry, of how these export schemes work in encouraging manufactures, the Henderson seat operation in Adelaide is a very good case in point. It started 12 months ago from nothing. It takes leather from another company, Howe Leather-a beneficiary of the export facilitation scheme, but almost lost because of the bungling of that aggressive bilateralism that the Minister for Trade( Mr Fischer) goes parroting on about. That bungling almost cost Howe Leather its business in Australia, but that has been patched up in some way that has not been completely divulged to the public. Henderson's takes Howe leather and makes a seat for a vehicle which is exported. Henderson's is not part of the Mitsubishi plant in Adelaide, but is peripheral to it. It supplies those seats just in time. Every two hours, seats are going out into export vehicles. This is an example of what the export facilitation scheme has done. This is an example of a company in car componentry, which has mushroomed all around the country as a result of the car plan and a commitment to exports-just as DIFF was a commitment to getting exports up. There are 200 of these companies in the automotive industry all around the country and in regions around the country, and all of them employing between one and 400 people. These are the companies that are now under threat because of actions that the government will take, it is suggested, if it adopts the majority recommendations of the Productivity Commission. We know what the Treasurer's stance is in all of this, because it was divulged over that cosy little dinner at the Commonwealth Club some two weeks ago-over cigars and port, the sort of nightcap that some of that side of politics revel in. Some even stay in this very lavish club, so they can afford to indulge a bit more. This is when the truth comes out, and the truth was, of course, revealed a couple of weeks ago. speaker: Mr Crean
theText: It might be another issue, but it is an issue that you cannot brush under the2508 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 to the growth of our manufacturing base, not committed to securing the continued growth of our heavy engineering industry and not going to continue to be clever with one of the important leverages available to government-that is, aid-to try not just to assist other countries, but at the same time to also use Australian manufactures in the process. Why shouldn't we be doing that? That is a win-win situation. That is the circumstance that we should all be aiming for. That is why we need a bipartisan approach to these issues. This is not an issue just of budget bottom lines. If you say that, you are essentially arguing that you cut regardless of the consequences. If you ignore the consequences of what has happened to the DIFF scheme as a result of the bungling and incompetence of the foreign minister, you also ignore the impact that that scheme has had on significantly growing the heavy engineering base in this country. DIFF is a vital arrow in the quiver, if you like, for going out into the international marketplace and trying to win the battle. There are many arrows that have to be in the quiver and they have to be selected, because some of them will apply differently to different targets. But that is the nature of trade. It is the nature of manufacturing. It is the nature of picking where your niche opportunities are. Not government picking it-not that at all-but government saying to industries, 'You get in there and compete on your own merits. But if, in fact, there isn't a level playing field, then we will try to level it up for you.' There is not another country in the world competing for these projects in developing countries that does not back its heavy engineering industry. It is only Australia that dud its industry and it is only the Liberals in Australia that dud it. Labor was prepared to have a scheme. It was prepared to develop DIFF and the Export Finance Insurar:ce Corporation. It was prepared to put the substance of government in partnership behind industry development. It is prepared to support the goers. You cannot just get up there and preach to manufacturers on the basis of, 'Get out there, chase exports and we will see what happens.' It does not work that way. It needs a partnership, and DIFF was a vital part of the partnership. The opposition, as I said, supports the measures that are before us today but it laments the circumstances in which it comes to us. It urges the government, and those who represent the government in this chamber today, to rethink its position, to restore the DIFF scheme, to honour its election promise in relation to DIFF and to keep the export market development grants scheme going. We urge them to adopt, in a bipartisan way, Labor's plan for the automotive industry. If the government does not do that, we will see not just one manufacturer close but maybe all of them, and that will be a sorry day for Australia. This is a circumstance in which we can build the strength of one of our great industries, just as we can build on the strength of our heavy engineering capacity. But it will not happen on its own. It requires a partnership. It requires government to be working with industry. The great tragedy of this government is that it is not prepared to work with industry. It thinks it understands industry but it just has no idea. The litany of complaints that comes through from businesses these days is about the government not listening to them and not being prepared to act. It is a sorry indictment on a party that claims to represent business interests that those businesses now have to tum again to Labor to try to argue their case. I hope the government takes note of our concerns. We are offering a preparedness to be involved in a bipartisan way in the development of a sensible industry policy for this country; one that embraces schemes such as DIFF and the export market development grants scheme. The simple fact is that people in business need to plan on a longer-term horizon than the term Wednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2509 of one parliament. Just as we give certainty in the economic direction-the treasury line, if you like-we need an industry direction or line. We need to create the environment for certainty against which businesses can invest; an approach of certainty that, regardless of changes in government, will carry on. That is an expectation that people had, when they went to the last election, in relation to the DIFF scheme. It is a promise dishonoured-one of many. The government should be shamed on that ground alone. But let us look forward to where these industries can be taken. Let us try to support the heavy engineering capacity of this nation. Let us re-establish the DIFF scheme, not just transfer the remnants of it to another arrangement against which those that were lucky enough to get in can still be administered. For all of those projects that were given the go-ahead, we require that that be honoured. I think that is the appropriate course for us to follow. We would certainly join in any change to arrangements that saw that happen. Finance and Insurance Corporation Amendment Bill 1997. BeforeI enter into the main thrust of what I want to say about this bill, I want to make some passing reference to the matters raised by the honourable member for Hotham( Mr Crean) before he leaves the chamber. The honourable member for Hotham should know that no business is debated in this chamber, no business at all, without agreement from the opposition. If he did not know, he should have known, and if he knew that he is about to leave the chamber, to criticise the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) for making alleged claims in regard to the Mitshubishi plant, when he knows very well the honourable Treasurer has denied that claim. He said, 'Labor was prepared to put a plan into action.' After 13 years, I think it lacks credibility when they come into this chamber and they say, 'We were going to put a plan into action.' You have had 13 years and you have done absolutely nothing. Ms Worth-Hear, hear! in talking about this very important issue, was to couch it in such a way that he knew-or he should have known-that what he was saying was intended to mislead, because the intention of EFIC and DIFF is to provide EFIC with a lot more flexibility than it had before. That is the intention of the changes in this bill. EFIC is a statutory corporation set up specifically, and in particular, to increase Australia's exports by the provision of internationally competitive insurance and export finance. speaker: Mr Zammit
theText: The other thing that I thought was distasteful from the member for Hotham,2510 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 business-I am going back some 22 years-I was importing a product from Germany and a similar product from other parts of the world. from Germany and from other countries, they approached me at a given time and said that they were willing to substantially increase the stockholding at no cost to me-very long termto repay over a period of, say, 12 to 15 months. BecauseI had that flexibility, I did not need to obtain the finance to import goods from the other parts of the world that were of a similar nature and similar in price. That meant that my emphasis was on that product from Germany almost to the exclusion of that similar product from other parts of the world. The Germans were able to establish a very strong foothold in Australia for a product that was not manufactured in Australia. What that meant was that they were able to lock out their competitors from other parts of the world. That is one of the added incentives that is there for the government to get strongly involved in export finance. As the minister stated in his second reading speech, in last year's budget the coalition government stated that DIFF loans would be divorced from EFIC and those liabilities transferred to the government's responsibility. The reason for that is the DIFF loans are invariably long-term loans, in the vicinity of up to 25 years. This restricted EFIC in its ability to assist small and medium sized enterprises with their requirements, which are invariably for much shorter terms, with faster turnover and thus being able to assist more enterprises because of the faster turnover. The clients of EFIC are invariably small and medium sized enterprises with a very smallish turnover, in the vicinity of up to about $50 million. These are exactly the sorts of enterprises that are strong in manufacturing that need a bit of a boost to enter the export market and to develop Australia's export drive, especially into the Asia-Pacific region. In his second reading speech, the minister detailed the comparisons. A DIFF grant of some $120 million, needed to develop the export market of a small to medium sized company, translates roughly to an equivalent soft loan through EFIC of something like $350 million. That means that, because of the restriction of the time, less money is available to provide the necessary moneys for export. That has restricted EFIC very strongly. As a result, the potential to assist small and medium sized enterprises with quicker turnover and shorter term loans has been greatly enhanced. In 1995-96, EFIC financed some $7.5 billion of Australian exports to more than 150 countries around the world, benefiting about 1,000 Australian enterprises. There is no doubt that a great deal of that business would have been lost because the availability of finance and the cost of export risk mitigation would have precluded those Australian enterprises from obtaining their share of the export markets around the world. The main function of a DIFF grant is to provide finance for Australia's overseas aid programs, which are invariably focused in the Asia-Pacific region. As a result, their exposure is concentrated in a small number of countries that are very regionalised just to the north of

theText: You are very welcome to it. I recall that, as I was importing these goodsWednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2511 Australia. Consequently, EFIC found itself in the very unenviable position of having the risk unevenly balanced. When Australian exporters approached EFIC for funds to export products of a non-aid type to the Asia-Pacific region, the problem was further exacerbated, especially in view of the fact that Australia's exports are growing exponentially into the Asia-Pacific region. In other words, the risk factor is concentrated and it meant that EFIC had to look at expanding the risk and, as a result, had to reduce the amounts of money available for this non-aid type export. The amendments will allow EFIC more room to move and to more efficiently expand loans for short to medium periods for enterprises wishing to export their goods, especially in the Asia-Pacific region. The Commonwealth will receive a special payment from EFIC of $40 million, which is intended to cover any potential losses that may occur, and the Commonwealth will pay EFIC a fee for managing the loans. This amendment will substantially strengthen EFIC's role, which is a niche that needed to be filled because the private sector was unwilling and/or unable or reluctant to provide risk venture capital in some overseas markets because of the risks involved-and quite understandably. EFIC was able to provide that much needed service. EFIC has demonstrated that it can meet most of the Australian exporters' requirements by operating on a commercial basis and paying its way, as well as building up reserves to meet potential future losses. In fact, not only has EFIC operated efficiently and effectively but, in addition, it has paid a dividend to the government during this financial year of $12.6 million. I strongly support the amendment to the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Amendment Bill 1997. this legislation, which really removes the liabilities for DIFF funding from EFIC to the Commonwealth account. I did not hear all of the contribution of the honourable member for Lowe( Mr Zammit), but I do not think he once mentioned that the government he is a member of has actually cancelled DIFF. The scheme no longer exists. I am not sure whether it is out of embarrassment or shame that he is unable to say it. DIFF is no longer there. It is all very well to say, 'EFIC is moving in and filling the gap,' but, in fact, it has not changed at all. It is certainly not changed by this bill, other than having a liability removed from it to the Commonwealth, and having to pay $40 million to the Commonwealth in consideration of the Commonwealth assuming liabilities for about $1.7 billion worth of loans. This whole sorry saga of DIFF funding needs to be again placed on the record. Let me be quite frank. The Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer), when in opposition-I think in about November 1995-asked the most comprehensive question on notice about DIFF funding to the then Minister Bilney and got a response. The coalition went into the election saying that they were going to maintain DIFF funding. Of course, we know once they were elected they cancelled it. One can only conclude that during the election there was dishonesty when the people of Australia were told that the coalition would maintain DIFF funding. We ought to reflect on the cancellation of this DIFF funding. The Development Import Finance Facility: why did we have it? In fact, it was the coalition that introduced DIFF funding in 1980. The first project under DIFF funding was approved in 1982-1 might say with Labor Party support; it was bipartisan-but they were the ones that actually originated the scheme. You would think that they would demonstrate some pride of ownership. I note that the member

theText: As you would be aware, the opposition is not opposing2512 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 for Wannon( Mr Hawker) will follow me in this debate. Perhaps he, or whoever is going to be the next coalition speaker, might exhibit a little bit of pride of ownership. him from contributing. DIFF funding is a mixed credit scheme which allows Australian companies to tender competitive contracts for the supply of Australian goods and services for projects in developing countries. Normally DIFF funding will cover an amount equal to 35 per cent of the contract and is combined with export credit from the Export Finance Insurance Commission of Austrade to provide a concessional loan to the recipient country. It has been very successful. In this debate we cannot say DIFF funding created a level playing field for Australian companies. Of course it did not. Other countries have far more concessional arrangements: Japan, Germany, the United Statescertainly not a level playing field. And you have abolished it. The government members over there have been party to the abolition of the DIFF scheme. The member for Lowe was very proud to tell the House his experience as an importer. I do not understand how that is relevant to a debate about how you assist on exporting, but be that as it may, let us be generous about that and accept it from the member for Lowe. I have never been an exporter but when I was involved in communications I well remember a Victorian based company, Ericssons. is not-a parochial interest. They put in, I think from memory, a $300 million bid into Indonesia for communications equipment. Quite frankly, when you discussed it with the officials there, it was not that it was an inferior bid; it was not that the equipment could not and would not have made a significant difference. But when push came to shove the decision really got around to what was the best form of financing-who was giving the better deal there. They were at a disadvantage. That meant that jobs in Ericssons were at risk. We keep on saying as parliamentarians-both sides, but we say it with a greater degree of genuineness-that we need to export more. Traditionally, in communications there have been very few exports. We were pushing companies like Ericssons into the export market. If they could not survive competitively in the bid with DIFF funding, how in the hell are they going to survive without DIFF funding? The member for Hotham( Mr Crean) has pointed out that this backflip by conservatives on DIFF funding and the actions of the Minister for Foreign Affairs at the beginning of their new term of office was a cause of extreme embarrassment, if not humiliation, for the minister and the government. theText: And a good part of Melbourne. I wonder if he is exhibiting-I am sure heWednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2513 narrowly focused. There they were not concerned about the announced cancellation of the scheme and, of course, that proved to be grossly misleading. We went through a series of exposures one day after another where, far from being indifferent or not concerned about the cancellation of the scheme, and having contacted the minister, the ambassador, or high commissioner, or even having written letters to the minister, he was forced to come into the House and, effectively, make a grovelling apology and have the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) make it clear to the people of Australia that he was on a warning. He had not been sin-binned; he had not been sent off, but he was on his warning. And so he deserved to be. But it brings no credit to this government to remove DIFF funding. We like to think in the Labor Party that we represent the workers and, indeed, we certainly strive to do that. We are absolutely concerned about jobs, about permanent jobs, and about growth in jobs and, given that obsession of ours, we are very concerned to ensure that the full range of measures is available to Australian industry and Australian services when they are producing here in Australia and, more particularly, when they are exporting. And it is quite clear that they need DIFF funding. I should have mentioned that there is a whole range of projects, involving some 50 companies in all, caught up by the cancellation of the scheme. If there is one thing that business really objects to, that narks them more than cutting expenditure, more than slashes, it is an inability to plan and know where a government is heading. And these companies were narked because the government did not say that they are going to cut the scheme off and give businesses some advance warning. They did it overnight, and projects that were in the middle of approval processes were caught up. Given that the coalition, the originators of the DIFF scheme, have now emasculated and removed it, perhaps the parliamentary secretary ( Mr Andrew Thomson) who is going to sum up in this debate might tell us when he comes to this place: what were the conditions? Does he agree with me? What were their reasons for implementing the scheme in the first place, and have those conditions changed? Is Australian manufacturing industry so absolutely robust, flushed with funds and success that it no longer needs DIFF, and what are the implications of the cancellation of DIFF? How many Australian jobs are going to be lost? How many Australian dollars' worth of exports are going to be lost because of the cancellation of DIFF funding? There is one other aspect of DIFF funding that I have not mentioned and that is that, yes, it certainly helps some companies get into the export business. But when you get into the export business, it does not conform to Australian accountants' theory of business. You do not get success in three months, or six months, or twelve months. The export business is a long-term business and you have got to be patient. You have got to be in there; you have got to prove yourself, and after a period of time one success will breed success again. So perhaps the parliamentary secretary might take the trouble to tell us how many Australian companies will be deterred from making that long-term commitment to exports. But how many will be deterred from making that long-term commitment to exports? Can he give us an estimate? Did he ask his department to look at this? Can it provide us with some figures? theText: I am pleased to see the honourable parliamentary secretary in the chamber.2514 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 many Australian jobs this means? What does it mean to services exports? What does it mean to manufacturing exports? I do not want to speak much longer in this debate; I want to make it clear fromto say this: the Australian Labor Party in opposition is most concerned to do all that it can do to work with industry. The member for Hotham talked about industry plans that had been put in place when we were in government. Of course we are proud of those industry plans. The essential feature of them is that you need, in the first instance, to sit down with the industry, whether that is management or the workers, to ascertain where they are and where they see the potential to be, and develop a plan based around that. Industry plans do not necessarily mean forking out taxpayers' dollars for assistance. For example, the car plan involved an export facilitation approach. This did not cost any dollars, but it put the car manufacturers on notice that they really had to export. Again, with communications, it was looking at the role of the dominant carrier and the new carrier, Optus, in trying to get as many dollars and jobs as they are able to pull through Australian industry. We are not embarrassed or ashamed of the fact that we are concerned about Australian jobs and Australian exports. We are prepared to sit down with industry to work through the impediments to growth and export to ensure that if there is a role for government to play in that, we will play it. I think that when we go to the next election, there will be a distinct contrast between a Treasury-led government indifferent to jobs and to firms surviving, and an opposition where we are concerned about Australian jobs, about growing Australian small and medium businesses and about developing plans that allow them to grow and to export. I think that when we go to the next election, the Australian people are going to see that we are reflecting their concerns on this. They are concerned about it. They are very worried about you mob over there because they believe that you have no commitment to Australian jobs or to Australian industry or services, and you may very well reap the reward of being indifferent to their concerns. We want to be assured on this side of the House that that does not happen to us. As I said, we support this bill, but I am looking forward to-I cannot stay-reading the parliamentary secretary's responseaddressing all the issues that I have raised for him so that the Australian people can be better informed about his government's motivation and reason and what actual numbers they have to back up the actions that they have taken. the opposition does not oppose this legislation, as such. However, the opposition is deeply concerned about the context in which this legislation comes to the parliament which, as previous speakers have said, arises from the government's decision, against its election commitments, to abolish the DIFF scheme. speaker: Mr Sercombe (Maribyrnong) (10.54 A.m.)
theText: As other opposition speakers have indicated,Wednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2515 supported almost $7.5 billion in Australian exports, up some 20 per cent. It had 240 new clients, most of which were small to medium enterprises, 60 per cent of which were manufacturers. Its insurance against non-payment increased by 14 per cent to $6.5 billion. It introduced export finance guarantees, which are a package of EFIC and bank arrangements which provide competitive, medium to long-term finance to Australian exporters. The first loan under that arrangement was made in July 1996 for a project in Thailand. We are talking about an organisation which is growing in importance in terms of Australia's export effort, and one which ought to be acknowledged, I am sure, on a bipartisan basis. But we need to understand, as other speakers have said, that EFIC and Australian exporters operate in a pretty competitive world, and a pretty competitive one in relation to access to finance and insurance. I had a look at some figures that were produced recently in an OECD publication. They are a little dated, but they show the scale of support from organisations comparable to EFIC in other countries with relatively small economies, such as Austria. In 1992, Austria provided cover for export contracts of some 296Y2 billion Austrian schillings. On a quick and dirty calculation, that works out at about over $A32 billion. Sweden's equivalent organisation to EFIC can incur liabilities of up to 72 billion Swedish kronor, which works out at about $A12'h billion. Germany, which the member for Lowe( Mr Zammit) referred to, at the end of 1991 had commitments of DM152 billion-on the OECD figures I had-for export credit insurance, working out at some $Al17 billion. I have a slightly more generous view of the example the member for Lowe gave about his experience as an importer than has the member for Chifley( Mr Price). In a somewhat garbled way, I must concede-and perhaps that is why he confused the member for Chifley-the member for Lowe was making a point, as an importer dealing with a German company, about just how important the package of financial support was that the German company was able to offer him. When you look at the figure of over DM152 billion as the level of commitment that the German equivalent to EFIC offers to its exporters, you can understand what a competitive world this country is operating in, and why it is so important that EFIC be supported. You can see what a tragedy it is for a range of Australian industries, particularly in the engineering area, that the government has proceeded to break its election commitments and abolish DIFF. EFIC's last annual report gives some examples of DIFF supported projects-the sorts of projects which are now not going to happen, which is going to place Australian companies at a huge competitive disadvantage compared with their overseas competitors. A $17 million project for China of machinery for filtering or purifying water is just one that springs to my attention, with the Overseas Project Corporation of Victoria having a project of $6.7 million for a water treatment plant in China. In Indonesia, the Vocational and Technical Training Corporation of Australia has a $27 million occupational health and safety project. In the Philippines, AWA has a project of $30 million for the upgrading and rehabilitation of existing metro-Manila traffic signal systems. These are just some of the projects listed in the EFIC annual report, projects which are simply not going to be there in future. Australian companies are simply not going to have a competitive advantage in obtaining those sorts of projects. I recently picked up another example in the Philippines of a $40 million BP solar project, which apparently is one of the last ones that slipped through the net, as it were, with EFIC making an announcement about providing a concessional loan which included a $13 million Australian government grant from AusAID. As I said, these are going to cost Australians jobs. 2516 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 They have also cost, and are going to cost, Australia a great deal in terms of its international reputation. If we were talking about an inefficient scheme, one that was not achieving its mark, one might argue that the government could have acted appropriately in wanting to review it. But in government budget papers, in Budget Related Paper No. 2 on the 1995-96 Australian overseas aid program, there is a report of the review by AusAID which says: The review also found that the DIFF had generated substantial commercial benefits for Australia. This is in addition to the earlier part of the report which talks about the benefits offshore to recipient countries of DIFF. The report goes on to say: Almost all firms surveyed reported that DIFF had been important to their business, with half stating it was either crucial or very important to their operations. Commercial returns from 51 of the 53 projectsinvolving some $285m of AusAID funds-were examined in detail. The 51 projects resulted in expenditure in Australia worth some $709m. Follow-on business already won by companies at the time of the survey, and directly related to the original DIFF project, was estimated at $263m. Firms indicated they expected to achieve further follow-on business, in the order of $400m, by the end of 1994. Companies indicated there was a range of significant, but non-quantifiable, benefits arising from the scheme. For many organisations, a DIFF project was their first overseas contract; several noted that undertaking the project had "internationalised" their firm and had changed their focus from solely concentrating on the domestic market to including a significant export orientation in their activities. Other important benefits arising from participation included: establishing credibility in international markets; enabling investments in plant and equipment; fostering new research and development initiatives; gaining international experience for staff; and setting up joint ventures. And so the report goes on. What this government has done is to throw out all those gainsgains which are directly quantifiable in many respects-and also many gains which, while not quantifiable, are clearly contributing and have contributed towards an export culture for Australian enterprises. It is a real tragedy that this has occurred. It has also been very damaging for Australia's international credibility. Media reports last year in the period when Alexander Downer, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, was making a real dill of himself on this issue, make that quite clear. In the Financial Review of 17 May, there is a quote from the Chinese Ambassador which says: "Should those projects be scrapped off, it would not only cause financial losses on the Chinese side, but also would do no good to the Australian side in terms of its credibility and business interests in China," he said. We are all aware that the Prime Minister is visiting China shortly. We wish him success in trying to repair some of the problems and issues that exist in that very vital relationship. But the government's performance in DIFF is undoubtedly one of the significant factors that significantly damaged Australia's position with China. In the same article that I have referred to in the Financial Review, the Philippines Ambassador attacked the government's decision. She said that the abolition of DIFF would be damaging to Australia's image in Asia. It certainly was damaging, and is damaging, in terms of Australia's reputation as a reliable long-term partner in a range of commercial activities. I come back to what, in some respects, is possibly the most important point of all, and that is that this government is putting Australian firms on an increasingly uneven playing field. There is no doubt that the Japanese, German, French, Italian and Spanish companies that will b.e competing for projects throughout Asia, the Pacific and elsewhere, and that are receiving Wednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2517 soft loans or mixed credits from their governments, are going to be in a substantially improved competitive position vis-a-vis Australian companies. That is simply stupidity on the government's part. Foreign Affairs) (11.05 a.m.)-It is my task, in the absence of the minister, to sum up the debate on this bill. It is really rather a small, perhaps technical bill in the greater scheme of things. It has come from a decision made in the process of the 1996-97 budget and it is essentially about improving the efficiency and effectiveness of EPIC, a government business enterprise that is of demonstrated value to our exporters. One of its roles in the past has been to deliver DIFF loans under an agreement with AusAID, the agency that I have some responsibility for. The government announced the scrapping of DIFF last year during the election campaign, a promise that was kept in the budget last year with some adjustment, and formed part of the government's deficit reduction strategy, which is a central plank of our economic policy. An unintended consequence of the use of EPIC in this role was pressure on EPIC's capitalisation, which was adversely affecting its ability to assist exporters in the two markets-Indonesia and China-where DIFF had been concentrating. It is a case perhaps of not wanting to put too many eggs in the one basket. As these loans were very long-term loans-in the case of Indonesia, 25 years-they were tying up a large amount of EPIC's capital. The EPIC board advised the government of this problem, that in effect there were too many eggs in the one basket. As a result, the government decided to remove DIFF's liabilities from EPIC and place them on the government's account. As the government will henceforth be directly assuming some $1.7 billion in liabilities for these loans, it was decided also that EPIC be required to transfer to the government some of the capital that it was holding as a measure against the risk of default on these loans. The figure of $40 million contained in this bill represents less than half the capital tied up by EPIC for these loans. The result is that it will dramatically free up EPIC's ability to provide mediumterm and long-term finance in support of our exporters, and for this reason of course it has the full support of EPIC's board. EPIC will continue to administer these loans and will be paid an administration fee by the government for doing so. The government will, however, be liable to reimburse EPIC for any losses occasioned by loan defaults or other interruptions to payment on the DIFF loans. I have not had perhaps as much opportunity to listen to the arguments put by opposition speakers on this bill, although I welcome their gracious act in supporting it. My friend the member for Chifley( Mr Price) I heard on the monitor as I was preparing to leave my office to make my way to the chamber. I believe he asked whether I had any pride of ownership in Australia's exports-perhaps that is what he meant. I simply ask: does the member for Chifley likewise have pride of ownership in the sort of disruption we see on our waterfronts? Or does he share pride of ownership perhaps in acts such as Mr Kelty's letter to Chubu Electric Power, advising them not to buy Australian coal? If that is the sort of thing that the organisation that supports his party is liable to do, I wonder if he would volunteer that same sort of pride. I have pride in lower interest rates, I have pride in a more flexible labour market, and I have pride in some of those Australian products such as our great wines, for' example. My friend the member for Wakefield ( Mr Andrew) is sitting here beside me and, indeed, I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, which are the finer wines, those from his electorate or those from yours? This argument could go on-

speaker: Mr Andrew Thomson (Wentworth
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for2518 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 but it does illustrate the point that where there is a debate about the quality of this product, it is plain to all of us that our wine is now perhaps the best in the world. It has acquired of its own right and as a matter of its inherent quality a franchise in certain export markets, in particular in Britain and increasingly in Europe and the United States. So in answering some of the arguments that have been put to the committee by members on the other side-such as, 'We have to export more and therefore we have to have some scheme, such as DIFF' I ask, 'Where was the DIFF funding for wine? And if there was no such scheme, why is it that our Australian wines have such a strong grip, such a strong franchise, on their markets?' Did they ever have such assistance? No. them to persuade people to exercise their preference as consumers in other markets and to buildtheir price is comparable to that of products of their competitors from France, California or, lately, Chile-I noticed in Japan that Chilean wines have made a great thrust into the Japanese market-it is on sheer quality, not on some sort of assistance scheme provided by the taxpayer. Frankly, that is about the best example I can draw on to demonstrate the folly of trying to facilitate exports of a product, rather than allowing the conditions to develop whereby its inherent competitive advantage would improve and therefore it would acquire a sustainable grip on an export market, not one that could be dashed by the intervention of another government with a cheque book. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. Second Reading Debate resumed from 4 December 1996, on motion by Mrs Moylan: That the bill be now read a second time. Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill 1996 by placing on record the opposition's continuing support for the review of the food standards code. We recognise that is a substantial undertaking for the Food Authority. The opposition also supports the stated intention of the bill to improve the planning and financial management of the Food Authority. But we question whether this bill will really bring about reform or whether it is more to do with budget cuts to the authority and the government setting up arbitrary charging powers for the authority to make up the shortfall which was announced by the government in the budget.
