speaker: Mr Lee (Dobell) (11.12 A.m)
theText: I would like to begin my contribution on the Australia NewWednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2519 The bill enables the government to make substantial savings by cutting funds to the Food Authority. It does so by setting up a process which allows the authority to charge applicants for dealing with their applications. The provisions which give the Food Authority these charging powers are extremely broad. The opposition believes they need to be far more explicit. The basis on which those charges can be levied appears arbitrary and possibly ill thought out. There is certainly not sufficient detail in this bill to demonstrate otherwise. The bill allows the Food Authority to impose charges or to waive them, but it does not provide sufficient information on how or why this will be done. I believe it would be far better if the government had provided explicit criteria for these circumstances. Similarly, it is of concern that there are apparently no guidelines for the Food Authority decisions on which applications will be treated as a priority. There is nothing in the legislation which indicates which particular food groups or applications will be processed free of charge and which will be subject to full cost recovery. I understand that the government might believe that regulations or some other administrative procedures might make that clearer. But, at this stage, the parliament is dealing with this bill unless we can have some draft regulations made available or the government can provide some greater clarity on this. I think that is to be encouraged. It is clearly in the interests of all parties to have a clear and explicit set of rules so that applicants know well in advance what procedures are to be followed and what charges will be involved in any application. It is also important that there be appropriate appeal mechanisms available. My understanding of the bill is that there is no provision for industry to appeal against a decision to impose cost recovery. The government is asking to be taken on trust on this important legislation, and I do not think that is good enough. The opposition has demonstrated in the past that we were prepared to deal constructively with proposals for genuine reform, but we do not look kindly on halfbaked savings schemes, especially not in an industry as important as this, with such enormous potential for future growth in exports. There is a real danger that this legislation, which is being introduced during a period of reform for the Food Authority, will undermine the current reform program-which would be a very unfortunate outcome for the industry and for Australian consumers. Whilst the opposition will not be seeking to oppose the legislation in the House of Representatives, that is on the basis that we understand that the legislation is going to be subject to close scrutiny in the Senate. Of course, the opposition reserves the right to move amendments in the other place. We will be hoping to consult not just with the industry but also with the government, the department and the Food Authority, to try to see if there are some amendments that perhaps in consultation we could put together to try to deal with the concerns that I have raised this morning. Senator Neal, on behalf of the opposition, is certainly willing to sit down with the industry and to see if there are suggestions that can be made for ways to improve the industry'S understanding of how the act will be administered. In my electorate there are two companies which might be known to members of the House and which will be affected by this bill. The Sanitarium Health Food Company and Master Foods have built substantial factories and employ a large number of my constituents. They are members of the Australian Food Council, 2520 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 which has raised a number of queries about their concerns about the arbitrary powers that are to be given to the authority to fix charges and to place certain levies on applicants. I will quote from one letter from the Chairman of the Australian Food Council, W. Murray Rogers. The letter describes the legislation in these terms: It is extremely disappointing, therefore, that the Government should introduce such broad and one-sided legislation at the very time that the entire industry is seeking to achieve a more cost-effective and efficient system of food regulations which can deliver safer, quality foods to consumers at the most competitive prices. Despite the unfortunate timing of this legislation, the industry will continue to pursue this objective with the Government. And that is certainly the shared objective of the opposition. Before the bill gets to a final vote in the Senate, we hope that we can clarify those concerns. The other issue I want to raise this morning is an issue I am sure some members of this house have heard some of the opposition members raise on many occasions, and that is the issue of chicken meat. I know that this bill does not directly deal with quarantine regulations and imports of chicken meat, but there was a so-called expert on radio this morning stating that he had concerns about the level of antibiotics fed to chickens, and about whether that results in people who consume the chicken meat-and, certainly, people who work with the chickens and are exposed to the antibiotics-having in their bodies viruses which could increase their resistance to these antibiotics. People are aware that there are some very aggressive diseases that are resistant to some of the best antibiotics in the world, and that some of these diseases can cause great distress and illness in some of our hospitals, both public and private. We need to be very careful about how we use antibiotics, in order to make sure that we are not the only century that has the ability to control diseases through the use of antibiotics. I understand that there are probably some industry codes that are followed by the chicken growing industry in Australia, codes that seek to put limits on the levels of antibiotics that are fed to chickens grown in Australia. I would be interested to know the answer to the question I raise in connection with this legislation-even if the minister takes it on notice, as I do not expect an answer off the cuff this morning. If the officials know, I am keen to know whether the Food Authority in Australia does actually set a limit on the level of antibiotics in any of our foods, and in particular, in chicken meat. If we do not do so already, should we have such a limit? In particular, if we do not have any such limits in Australia, what action do we intend to take against the possible importation of Thai chicken meat, which I am informed is subject to much less rigorous standards? Chickens grown in Thailand apparently are fed much larger concentrations of antibiotics. I am sure that means that more chickens survive, but it also means that those of us who consume the chicken meat are ingesting higher levels of antibiotics. In the long term that might mean we have diseases in Australia that are resistant to antibiotics and that may become more common in Australian hospitals. That would be a retrograde step. I know this issue is not directly connected to the bill, but can we get some advice on whether we have any standards on levels of antibiotics? I am not even sure that we can measure these concentrations-because they might be quite low-or whether we simply rely on the practices of various industries to limit their use of antibiotics. As I say, the opposition is generally supportive of the aims of the legislation but we have reservations about the arbitrary powers given to the authority. We would be hopeful that Wednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2521 further consultations with the government and the industry might allow us to clarify, if not resolve, some of those concerns. Food Authority Amendment Bill 1996. This bill will enable the authority to establish a standards review work program which will set priorities for food safety, consumer protection, and international and industry harmonisation issues over the next three years. The bill therefore redresses deficiencies in the current legislation which prevent the authority from having the capacity to plan, manage and prioritise its workload. The amendments change the statutory obligation to finalise applications within 12 months. The authority will no longer have to assess applications on a first come, first serve basis and it will no longer be obliged to assess each application individually. Current requirements have prevented the authority in the past from undertaking comprehensive and thorough reviews of groupings of foods. No-one here would dispute the importance of the Australia-New Zealand food industry. In Australia that industry is worth over $40 billion per year and this figure is, of course, substantially higher when the New Zealand industry is included. We would all agree that Australia enjoys an extremely close relationship with New Zealand, both culturally and geographically. We have no language barriers. We share a common colonial heritage which means that our food, in particular, is similar. It costs less to transfer food between Australia and New Zealand than it often costs to transport it from one side of Australia to the other. Thus this bill, which helps facilitate the food exchanges between the two countries, is of enormous mutual economic advantage to the two countries. New Zealand has a population of 3.64 million and that provides it with a food market in Australia roughly six times that of its own domestic market. New Zealand is our third largest trading partner; the trans-Tasman food trade is now worth more than $1 billion annually. This bill builds on the cooperative and mutually beneficial economic and trade framework first developed under the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement. It is a logical extension of that agreement and it is part of our building on that agreement. We expect that the outcomes of these amendments will provide an even closer model of cooperation, one that other people in this region look to as a model of coordination, cooperation and mutual satisfaction. Already, the closer economic relations trade agreement between Australia and New Zealand has eliminated barriers to trade between the two countries and it has led, in particular, to the creation of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. In many ways, this authority complements the new Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Bill-which was recently in the House and debated in this chamber-which will allow goods legally sold in an Australian jurisdiction to be sold in New Zealand without further testing and vice versa. Producers only have to ensure that their products comply with the laws in the home country in order for them to be available and saleable in the other. The new Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Bill, for example, opens up substantially new opportunities in the confectionery and dairy manufacturing areas. We can therefore expect, with the passage of the new Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Bill, a substantially greater workload for the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. The amendments contained in this that increased workload. The two bills are a step towards mutual recognition and harmonisation
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs Stone (Murray) (11.21 A.m.)
theText: I speak today in support of the Australia New Zealand2522 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 of food standards between Australia and New Zealand and this, of course, has implications for a greater food trade beyond the two countries and into Asia. The National Food Authority-that is, the Australian Food Authority-was formed in 1991, in consultation with industry, governments and the community, to ensure uniformity in food standards across Australia. Australian governments accepted the food standards as recommended by the national authority. In 1995, New Zealand joined and legislation was passed forming the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. This ANZFA initiative allows for a joint food standards setting system for Australia and New Zealand. As I said before, it provides for harmonisation of food standards and consumer information on the ingredients in foods between the two countries. The authority is responsible for developing, varying and reviewing standards for food available in Australia and New Zealand, as well as coordinating national food surveillance and recall systems. The authority is funded by the Australian and New Zealand governments, as well as by industry. In particular, the objectives of the authority in developing or varying standards are, chiefly: the protection of public health and safety; the provision of information to consumers to enable them to make informed choices about foods; to prevent fraud and deception; the promotion of fair trading in food and the promotion of trade and commerce in the food industry. As well, the authority aims to achieve the harmonisation of Australian and New Zealand food standards with international food standards, provided that those standards are not lower than the Australian and New Zealand requirements. At present, we are faced with the unacceptable situation where the Australia New Zealand Food Authority is unable to meet its management objectives, or to effectively develop any comprehensive joint food standard systems or, indeed, to harmonise food standards and consumer information. This situation has arisen due to the current regulatory and legislative framework which, as I mentioned before, places severe restrictions on the authority'S flexibility and ability to control its own targets, priorities and management plans. In particular, the authority needs assistance in achieving its main objectives and targets as it aims to produce a food standards code by March 1998. Given the importance of the growing economic relationship between Australia and New Zealand, it is essential that we address the problems created by the current framework of to be totally efficient are, firstly, that the authority, as I said before, has no control over a number of applications it is legally bound to handle at anyone time. It must accept all applications that meet certain basic criteria. As well, the authority currently has a legal obligation to complete the relevant assessment of each application within 12 months, regardless of the circumstances and where the application fits in relation to public safety or industry priorities. If there is an urgent requirement the authority cannot bend its rules. The authority must assess the applications in order of receipt, effectively on a first come, first served basis, irrespective of any more urgent demands or later applications. The authority also has an obligation to assess each application individually. This leads to a fragmented response and approach to food standards and it undermines the important principle that the National Food Authority has, which is that it should achieve a coordinated, thorough and effective response to assessing food standards throughout Australia and New Zealand. In particular, the authority cannot respond urgently to public health and safety Wednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2523 matters. It must take the products as they come in to it, strictly in order of first in, first to be dealt with. These proposed amendments will help to advance the authority to a position where it will be a leader in the field of setting and monitoring food standards internationally. They will also help, as I said before, to ensure cooperation and the continued advancement of the mutuality between Australia and New Zealand in relation to trade in food products, and in doing so will advance the closer economic ties between the two countries. This new program will be supported by industry, the states, the territories in Australia, and New Zealand. All major stakeholders will be consulted. In terms of setting the new work plans that this amendment makes possible, the industry will be consulted in order to ascertain which priorities are pre-eminent in the industry. The main players will be consulted. They include federal, state and territory governments in Australia, as well as New Zealand. Applications that are given a priority will be assessed within 12 months and without charge. Other applications that do not fall within the new priorities of the three-year work plan will still be accepted and assessed, but on the basis of cost recovery or fee for service. If the relevant charges are not paid, the assessment will be able to be delayed until the charge is paid. This latter amendment is in line with the contemporary approach to cost recovery and with industry cooperation and commitment to their own regulatory regimes. It gives the industry greater flexibility and autonomy. The industry can set its own priorities and it can control its own future. There are a number of recent cases in Australia where the standards of food have caused major community concern. For example, we had a recent scare with Kraft Foods and their peanut products. This is an example where, if you have a more flexible authority, you can have urgent and instant action. We have seen the damage when food safety is allowed to be compromised. In fact, in that case it has cost the industry many millions of dollars both in reclaiming a lost market share and in having to recall their product. Nestle Australia discovered that, under the old regime, if their frozen food is prepared in Australia, New Zealand health standards require that the chicken be cooked for longer than required in Australia, even though in Australia we agree that the cooking times and temperatures are adequate for public health safety. Without harmonisation, Nestle has to have special runs in cooking product that is to be exported to New Zealand. This involves cleaning a line each time and a changeover of production schedules. There is no doubt that food standard harmonisation is essential for costeffective industry. It is also essential for the safety of all consumers. In my electorate, SPC fruit products, the canners, have complained that since New Zealand joined the food authority the time taken to process applications has increased. They have expressed considerable support for these amendments, understanding that under these amendments the times will again be reduced and they can get on with exporting the best possible product with minimum red tape and time required for them to address multiple layers of bureaucracy. As outlined previously, the authority will now be able to charge fee for service for assessments that are not classed as priority issues under their three-year work plan. That is very important for a government which sees industry paying its way. 2524 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 The national food regulatory framework, and this new ANZFA in particular, underpins consumer confidence in the safety of Australian and New Zealand food supplies. Its maintenance and its standards, its integrity, is therefore of enormous value to both countries and, as I said before, to our exports. As I noted before, industry is one of the main beneficiaries of the work of this authority. Industry will now contribute more substantially to covering the costs but industry will also be a partner in the authority's new ability to be flexible with its work plans. It is a win-win situation all round. The country of origin labelling laws in Australia and New Zealand are a critical part of our food standards, and as we march together to comply with World Trade Organisation standards, new flexible arrangements with the ANZFA bill will make sure that our food labelling is as coherent and transparent as possible, and that our products are immediately recognisable in terms of their contents and their standards of safety. This is a very important bill. The amendments to be introduced will substantially improve our ability as two countries-Australia and New Zealand-to have the world's safest food products. It also means that our products can be seen internationally as being of the highest standard. There is no doubt that, with the markets in Asia burgeoning only a very short distance from us, there is increased emphasis on the quality of the foods that all nations consume. These qualities include being able to identify that there are very few additives, that there are minimum chemical levels, that the food is fresh and absolutely complies with what its labelling states. In fact, this new set of amendments makes sure that, into the future, Australia and New Zealand will be known internationally as countries that produce the best foodstuffs in the world. Dr THEOPHANOUS (Cal well) (11.36 a.m.)-I want to commend some of the positive comments which the member for Murray( Mrs Stone) has made about the National Food Authority. Having been the parliamentary secretary responsible for the authority in the three year period of the last Labor government, and having been involved directly in the negotiation of the treaty which formed the Australia New Zealand Food Authority., I take a keen interest in the development of the authority. It is good to see the officers of the authority here. Having said that, I must say that I am very concerned at a problem which has arisen. The member for Murray was mistaken in her comment that industry is happy with this bill. I do not know where she gets that idea from, because the key industry organisations are very concerned about this bill. I might say thatpay close attention to the comments I am going to make. The situation is that, during the period of the previous Labor government-and certainly when I was parliamentary secretaryall issues concerning the National Food Authority were dealt with in a very consultative way with industry. Indeed, I worked together with representatives from consumer organisations, industry and other stakeholders from state governments. I used to often bring these representatives together, or ask the authority to bring the representatives together, and we would discuss these issues. If a matter arose, as it did, for example, with the country of origin exercise, the labelling exercise which was very long and difficult and where there were significant differences of view, even then we brought people together ..
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper
theText: Are you opposing the bill?
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Dr Theophanous
theText: I will explain what I am doing on the bill-you just keep quiet andWednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2525 Therefore, I was a bit shocked to see that the peak body of the food industry in Australia, the Australian Food Council, has written to the opposition and basically they are so concerned with this bill that they say in their conclusion: Our concerns are so fundamental that the preferred course of action is the withdrawal of the bill pending resolution of the ongoing debate about the imposition of charges in the industry. Simple amendment cannot satisfy these concerns. The industry wrote to the Prime Minister( Mr Howard). We are not just talking about one food industry, we are talking about the Council of Food Industries. They wrote to the Prime Minister expressing their concerns about this bill and the issues that were raised. As I say, what is really puzzling to me is the poor administration in this government which has led to this situation. I do not blame the authority. I do not blame the industry. I blame whoever was responsible in the government-and, of course, it is a bit difficult to determine who was responsible because we have had changes of the relevant parliamentary secretary-but, nevertheless, whoever was responsible has not done his job. A good job has not been done here because you cannot go to the parliament with a bill that is so universally opposed by the major industry with which it is dealing. This is a very reasonable point. As the shadow minister, Michael Lee, has indicated, although we will allow passage of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill 1996, we will be moving amendments in the Senate. Those amendments are intended to take account of the concerns not just of industry but also of others in relation to the issues which have been raised. As I say, I am puzzled that we got to this position because, as someone who was involved so intimatelyvirtually on a daily basis-in matters concerning the National Food Authority, I have been happy to see all the developments in the closer economic relations that have taken place between Australia and New Zealand because of the formation of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority and as a result of the different aspects that we have taken up. It is a unique structure. We are not objecting to the idea that there have to be certain other provisions to deal with the workload of the authority. But the question is: does this bill adequately deal with those? We do not believe that it does. The shadow minister, Michael Lee, indicated that there are certain serious problems because there are not specific regulations put forward. Maybe it is the intention of the government to bring specific regulations to help determine which of these groups are going forward as non fee for service and which are going forward as fee for service. It appears that we do not have any indication of those regulations and that is one of the things that we will be asking to have a look at. One of the concerns raised by the industry is that it is going to give the food authority the ability, as it is presently worded, to charge willy-nilly in relation to the industry. There are two basic concerns. Firstly, because it is unclear which are going to fall within the charged group and which are not-and it is left very much up to the authority-there will be a real risk that the authority increasingly and effectively will, as the letter from the food council says, push applications into the fee for service category and levy charges at any figure it determines, subject to the taxation caveat discussed in the legal opinion which has been presented on this matter. It seems to me that this objection has not been dealt with. No-one is saying that the authority is inefficient, or anything of that sort, but let us assume that under the current administration anything can happen. If we have a situation in the future, there could be an incentive for the 2526 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 authority, as the food council says, to push applications into this fee for service category when they should have been in the other category, and then impose further burdens on the industry. Already we are saying that one of the reasons we formed the Australia New Zealand Food Authority was that we wanted to streamline the determination of food standards at the state level, at the federal level and with New Zealand into the one body, to have not only uniformity for consumers but also efficiency in terms of the charges which are put on industry. I do not think that it is an unreasonable request from industry to seek clarification of this. One has to ask why the Prime Minister has not responded to these concerns of industry which were raised with him by the chairman of the Australian Food Council on 9 December 1996. I would be interested to see what the minister's answer is to that. The situation is that we are interested in getting this bill through and in getting the main ideas of this bill through, but we are not going to support clauses which effectively are going to totally alienate the very industries that the food authority is supposed to be dealing with. That would be totally counterproductive and I cannot understand why this has taken place. I will now go to the other point, which is this question of the authority having the ability to determine which applications fall within, and which fall without, its predetermined work programs. In principle, that does not sound too bad, and one might say that they can have a look at the work program. But one has got to ask: if the authority is aware of the situation, and it knows that some applicants have a good ability to pay and others do not, then it might be tempted to predetermine its work program on the basis of saying, 'We know that this lot is not going to have the ability to pay, and we know that this group has the ability to pay.' Therefore, an arbitrary selection, or a selection based on the possible ability of the applicant to pay rather than on the merits of the work program, could make a determination. This reinforces the need for some kind of regulation or indication about the work program to be put in the context of this bill. It is true that the industry does have a representative on the committee looking at the work program but, of course, there is no necessity for that representative to be listened to. I think that in dealing with industry-at least this was my experience when I was parliamentary secretary--especially in this regulatory area, it is always good to have them on side about these matters. It is not as if the industry says, 'We will not pay.' One of the things that I certainly achieved, and even my predecessors achieved, was the agreement of industry to pay their fair share in this process for the National Food Authority. But when there are concerns about equity, when there are concerns about the application of the system, it is time for the authority and the minister responsible to talk again to industry and come out with some resolution. That is the general structure of my comments about the bill but I want to say that we can resolve this in a positive way if the minister wishes to discuss it with the industry. We in the opposition are happy to discuss it. In other words, I am talking here about a constructive resolution of the problem. We think that it is possible to bring together industry, other stakeholders and the Food Authority to find a way out of this impasse and achieve the goals of allowing the authority to have certain structured work programs, as well as achieve the goals of equity and of an efficient charging system-and keep the parties quite happy in the process. This is not an impossible job. I can say that there were much more impossible and difficult jobs than this one that the Food Authority and I had to negotiate. The honourable member for Murray referred to one of those. We have to take a grip on ourselves and ask, 'Do we really Wednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2527 want a battle in this situation?' I have indicated very clearly that, if the government persists with this approach, we will move amendments in the Senate and we will seek to gain the support of the minor parties for our amendments so as to be sure that the concerns of industry and of others are met in relation to the comments that I made. I conclude by saying something about the interrelationship between the Food Authority and the recent actions that have been taken to move everything back to state governments. I give a word of warning, now that we are discussing the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill, about the general tendency of the coalition government to push things back onto the states. I hope that we are not going to be tempted to hand back powers that currently exist in the Food Authority to the state governments. One· of the things that came out during the period I was parliamentary secretary was the frustration we had about the fact that far too many of the features that involved ensuring that the rules and the laws were actually met rested on state governments. We should be thinking about a national enforcement regime in food standards if we are really going to try to prevent the sorts of sensational cases that happen, such as when the little girl died in Adelaide because of salami poisoning. That had a dramatic impact on the whole of that industry for a long time. When we look at what happened, the Food Authority had done everything properly. The problem was that the government of South Australia had not, in terms of enforcement of food standards. The minister who is going to be responsible for the Australia New Zealand Food Authority in the future should be aware that we need to look at that issue. It is all very well to set standards, to have consumer protection councils looking at things and to have proper labelling-and that has been one of the big issues on which ANZFA has done a great job-but in the final analysis, you have to look at the enforcement of standards. This is where many of the state governments have starved it of resources, and yet they feel when it suits their interests that perhaps they ought to think about taking back some of the powers that have been given to the Food Authority. I think any such pressure should be totally resisted. We should be looking at the opposite, which is to increase the powers of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority in the enforcement area. (Time expired) my colleagues in this place on the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill, it is obvious that the Australia New Zealand Food Authority is held in fairly high regard. as is the work it has done since it was established in 1995. The aim of this bill is to enable the Food Authority to better manage, plan and prioritise its workload. I suspect that no-one would be opposed to such an idea. It is important that Australia maintains its reputation for clean food. It is eminently sensible, given the closeness of the relationship between this country and New Zealand, that we have cooperative arrangements such as that set up when the National Food Authority became the Australia New Zealand Food Authority in 1995. That legislation enabled the full participation of New Zealand, with the aim of having common food standards and common food quality between the two countries across the Tasman. Increasingly, we are becoming a single market. It has been pointed out that it is wise, wherever possible, that common standards exist. The honourable member for Cal well (Dr Theophanous) stressed the need for a national approach and for national standards. Most people
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (11.56 A.m.)
theText: When one listens to many of the comments made by2528 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 would agree that it would be ridiculous to vary standards but, equally, it would be a nonsense to have differing standards in Australia and in New Zealand. I wish to question, however, the competence of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority in the way in which it seems to be determined to damage the health of Australians by increasing the level of cadmium which is permissible in foods. The Australia New Zealand Food Authority has failed to consult widely with respect to its proposal to increase the level of cadmium from 0.05 milligrams per kilogram to 0.1 milligrams per kilogram. This approach by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority has concerned me greatly. While I support the principles of this legislation, I am worried that within the legislation we find that the Australia New Zealand Food Authority is able to bring forward proposals which will undermine the productivity and incomes of Australian food producers. In addition, it will be placing in jeopardy the health of Australians of various ages. I have received numerous representations from around my electorate from people who are extremely concerned at the proposal to increase the acceptable cadmium levels in foods and, in particular, in peanuts. Until recently it was considered gospel that cadmium is extremely dangerous in foods beyond 0.05 milligrams per kilogram. Research has indicated that long-term exposure to cadmium might lead to considerable accumulation in the liver and kidneys, particularly in the renal cortex, resulting in liver damage. The Australian and New Zealand Food Authority recently decided that cadmium levels could safely be increased to 0.1 milligrams per kilogram without affecting the health of consumers. This appears to run contrary to research done throughout the world which indicates that what we should be doing is seeking to reduce the level of cadmium, rather than increasing it. Yet the Australia New Zealand Food Authority appears to be heading along the direction of increasing the level of cadmium. I see that as being totally unacceptable and I hope that the Food Authority rethinks this proposal. It ought to be noted also that the main argument advanced by the food authority for increasing the level of cadmium, particularly with respect to peanuts, is that this is a non-tariff barrier excluding the importation of peanuts to this country. The simple fact is that every peanut producing country in the world can meet the Australian standards for cadmium and I have to ask: why should the Australian New Zealand Food Authority seek to expose the Australian public to twice the cadmium level when there is simply no need? At present, there is no restriction on the importation into Australia of peanuts which meet the current guidelines as peanut producing countries throughout the world have no difficulty in meeting the standards which we currently have. Australian producers, and particularly those in the South Burnett and Kingaroy areas of my electorate, have worked very hard over many years to ensure that their peanuts are as free as possible from cadmium and other residues. Cadmium is a heavy metal that is possibly a major contributor to kidney disease and it can cause bone disorders. High risk groups include young children, pregnant women, vegetarians and smokers. Given the very real concerns and the fact that there has not been adequate consultation, I think it is important that the Australian New Zealand Food Authority re-considers this matter. There have been some studies done in Sweden and I wish to refer to an article in a publication in August 1996. It says: ... exposure to cadmium can give rise to a tubular kidney dysfunction which may proceed to a more generalised renal damage and bone disease if exposure has been high and prolonged. Recent scientific Wednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITfEE 2529 work shows that early renal effects develop at lower levels of exposure than previously anticipated. Previous risk assessments for cadmium were mainly based on studies on healthy male workers. The general population, however, also include particularly susceptible groups such as elderly and individuals with illnesses (e.g. diabetes) that may predispose the cadmium-induced health effects. A significant proportion of the general population displays early signs of toxicity already at urinary cadmium concentrations around 3 mmol creatinine. In addition to early tubular effects, cadmium may exert direct or indirect effects on mineral metabolism and the materialization of the skeleton at relatively low levels of exposure. This may have important health implications as poor and easily fractured bones is a major problem among the elderly in all industrialised countries. It is interesting to note that in Sweden the cadmium content in wheat has increased during the 20th century, but that concentrations in Swedish food are still much lower than in food from, for example, cadmium polluted areas of Japan. The article says: Comparisons between the Cd concentration in human kidneys preserved at anatomical museums in Sweden and in kidney samples obtained in recent decades show that the kidney and body burdens of Cd have increased severalfold during the last century. There is no reason to believe that the situation in Sweden with regard to cadmium pollution is worse than in many other places and clearly cadmium pollution is a global problem. So, in the face of this evidence from Sweden, we find the Australian New Zealand Food Authority is moving to increase the level at which food in this country is able to be riddled with this heavy metal. This is absolutely unacceptable. It is interesting to note, too, that the National Food Authority had a cadmium workshop in Canberra in 1995 where it was considered that all regulatory bodies should work to put in place a strategy to minimise the exposure of the Australian population to cadmium by reducing cadmium in fertilisers and by maintaining maximum permissible content. Therefore, the activities of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority appear to be running contrary to the recommendations from this particular workshop. I believe that the food authority really has a case to answer. The Food Authority ought to be looked at very closely. This legislation currently before the House is legislation which is supported broadly by both sides of politics. Clearly, it is important not to force the authority to divert all of its resources to the handling of applications and that, indeed, it ought to get on with its other work. I have no complaint with any of that but my constituents are extremely concerned that the authority seems determined to double the level of cadmium which is deemed to be acceptable in Australia. There were two proposals to go before the Commonwealth, state, territory and New Zealand ministers for health and these were proposals 148 and 144. Proposal 148 sought to double the permitted levels of cadmium in peanuts from 0.05 milligrams per kilogram to 0.1 and proposal 144 seeks to achieve a general increase in permitted cadmium levels. I have outlined the situation in relation to peanuts and how this could create increased health problems for Australians. It now seems, however, that the Food Authority has said that while it is not going to proceed with proposal 148, which deals with peanuts in isolation, it is going to impose increased cadmium levels on all Australians in relation to all food products. That is clearly unacceptab Ie. It is interesting to note that a very reputable member of the Queensland community, in fact, the president of the Queensland grain growers association, has opposed strongly what is proposed by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. It is very hard to find supporters out there in the community for the proposal of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. I have heard it reported that pressure is being imposed on the ANZ Food Authority because 2530 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 apparently there has been a consignment of condemned peanuts already in the country and the intention is to increase the level of cadmium to permit these condemned peanuts to be inflicted on the Australian community. I think the Australia New Zealand Food Authority needs to answer some questions here. It is unacceptable that the authority should be acting contrary to the health interests of Australians. All of the evidence, both in Australia and elsewhere, shows that we should be moving towards reduced cadmium levels and yet the Australia New Zealand Food Authority seems hell bent on doubling the maximum permissible levels in Australia. As the Swedish studies indicate, such an action by the authority could well impact on the health of not only young Australians but also older Australians. However, the government is to be commended for this legislation. It will improve the procedures of the Food Authority. It will enable the authority to concentrate not on applications but rather on the very major projects at which the Food Authority is looking. I ask at this stage that the government, and particularly the minister, look closely at the authority's advocacy of doubling the levels of acceptable cadmium in Australian food with a view to preserving the present levels which I believe is in the interests of reasonable health standards for Australians. I commend the bill to the Committee. debate on the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Bill, particularly as the standards that apply to Australian food are of such essential importance to every Australian. It is true that we have an image of which we are justly proud, an image as a clean and green producer of Australian food. In fact, we have a reputation as a country which ensures that most Australian consumers can be assured that what they pick up from the shelf of Australian supermarkets, or acquire through their retailers, comes with recommendations that ensure that the health of the consumer will not be put at risk. It is fair to say that so good is our reputation as the provider of clean and green food and foodstuffs that Australians generally take that reputation for granted. The member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) in his participation in this debate referred to the very tragic circum-tances surrounding the Garibaldi case-a case with which I am familiar because the young girl who died as a result of the food poisoning contracted in the Garibaldi case happened to be resident in my electorate. That, mercifully, is very much the exception. Every Australian travelling overseas returns to Australia breathing a sigh of relief that the standards applying here are so much more rigorous than those applying in other countries around the globe. In fact, in order to ensure that the standards are consistent trans-Tasman, that there is a level of cooperation between Australia and New Zealand in policing Australian food standards, we have in place the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. It is the amendments to the act that has set that authority in place that we are dealing with in this debate this afternoon. It is fair to say that Australians, as I indicated earlier, tend to take food standards for granted. It is also fair to say that the focus of this debate has been on the opposition's particular concern about the proposal in the amendments that we are considering in this debate to allow the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to charge for some of the services that it offers. I understand the concerns expressed by the opposition, although I thought it was a little inconsistent for the member for Calwell to say that he was desperately bothered about all of this, but he would not oppose the legislation. I also felt it was a little inconsistent for the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Andrew (Wakefield) (12.09 P.m.)
theText: I welcome the opportunity to participate in thisWednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2531 member for Dobell( Mr Lee) to imply that there was some sort of inadequate standard being policed in Australia and that, under existing arrangements in Australia, so far as he knew, it may be possible for higher levels of antibiotics to apply in Australian food than he would find acceptable. In my participation in this debate I want to pick up two points. Firstly, I want to make a comment or two about what I see as the general standard of Australian food and, secondly, to refer specifically to the legislation and the proposal to allow the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to make some charges for some of the services that it is delivering. My background, as most of the parliament knows, has been in the food industry as a fruit grower. I can reassure this chamber and the parliament that standards do apply and that every fruit grower is conscious of that in terms of the fruit supplied to any retail outlet across Australia. The member for Calwell is to be commended, as indeed is the former government, for the work done in bringing state and national standards into some sort of uniformity. That was important. I thought the member for Calwell might have been a little more generous in his remarks, had he recognised that part of the Garibaldi disaster had occurred as much under a Labor Party state administration as any other. But that sort of generous comment was not something that he was volunteering in this debate. Nonetheless, as the parliamentary secretary he played a key role in ensuring that these standards were made uniform. The result of this is that food producers, food processors and food retailers across the nation are obliged to adhere to a standard which ensures that spray residues, antibiotics, and any other things that are seen as deleterious to human health are kept to an absolute minimum; a minimum that is seen as more than adequate by any of the other standards applying around the globe. As a fruit grower, I was obliged to ensure that if any form of spray had been used on the fruit that was being produced then that fruit was not harvested until it had met particular withholding periods. I also knew, as did all of the people who were fruit growers around me-and that includes those people from ethnic backgrounds who were without the same capacity to soak up the immediate information as those with European backgrounds automatically were-that anyone of the deliveries made to, say, a fruit processor or a fruit canner had to meet minimum standards and that there would be random regular selections of processed fruit off the line that would be assessed for its contaminant free status. So Australians, generally, have little to fear from the foods that they consume and from the standards that are applied. Of course there are exceptions. The member for Cal well focused on one of those exceptions. The most recent food scare, which concerned the Amott's biscuit chain, had nothing to do with producers or processors, but very much to do with what was little more than a terrorist attack. Nonetheless, the Australian community and Australian retailers ensured that every step was taken to make sure that Australian consumers could be assured that the food they were consuming was of the very highest possible standard. The Australia New Zealand Food Authority was set up so that we could ensure that the standards that apply across Australia would apply across the Tasman, in New Zealand. The first point of the authority was to develop and maintain an Australia New Zealand food standards code. The second was to develop and implement new hygiene standards for food processing, manufacturing and handling. The third was to ensure that national arrangements were in place for the surveillance and for compliance with the code. This has largely been successful. 2532 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 But, as a result of the involvement of the New Zealanders in what was once an Australian standard, we now have a situation in which the workload that the authority is facing is larger than it can reasonably process in order to meet the March 1998 deadline originally set down for the authority to have firm trans-Tasman arrangements in place. The authority has come to the government saying that it has no control over the number of applications made to it for compliance with these standards and that it is obliged under the existing legislation to deal with the applications on a first come, first served basis, so it cannot accurately assess the relevant importance of some applications over others-and even if it could, it cannot process them as it would choose to. It also has the problem that every application that comes to it must be individually assessed, even if it parallels another application on which the authority has already made a determination. For those reasons, the authority has asked for these changes. The member for Cal well has said that the changes proposed do not meet with the approval of the Australian Food Industry Council. He indicated that the particular concern the council had was a concern over the charging regime, and the member for Dobell tends to have reinforced that point. What has been overlooked in this debate is that the advice of the Attorney-General( Mr Williams) on the charging regime that is being proposed is that any fee charged under this legislation must be related to the expense incurred. The Attorney-General has indicated that some of the activities cannot be characterised as a service and, consequently, the costs will not be fully recovered, so there is still an obligation on the government to make an input into the way in which the Australia New Zealand Food Authority goes about exercising its important task. Furthermore, the Attorney-General's office has indicated that existing constitutional arrangements mean that we cannot impose a charge which would constitute a tax. So much of the concern expressed, justifiably, by the member for Calwell on behalf of the Australian Food Industry Council is a concern that the government knows is unfounded. This is not a proposal to find a way to tax the industry. In fact, the industry should be aware of that. The government not only indicates that in the second reading speech by the Minister for Family Services( Mrs Moylan), but it is reinforced by the advice gained from the Attorney General's office. I will quote a portion of the minister's second reading speech where she said: The bill: . pennits regulations to set the amount of the charges and to waive, remit and refund charges in whole or in part; and . specifically limits the level of the charge to recovering the authority's expenses in assessing an application. I therefore suggest that much of the concern expressed about this charge regime is unfounded and is, in fact, scaremongering. There is no intent by the authority or the government that these charges should provide a revenue raising measure for the government. I want to pick up a couple of other points that have come out of this debate and reinforce the remarks made by the member for Murray( Mrs Stone) when she said that, in her own electorate, the SPC people had found, following the movemeni of New Zealand into the authority to make the Australia New Zealand Food Authority complete, that there had been delays in their processing applications that they were anxious to have accelerated. The legislation before the House is designed to allow the government to accelerate these applications and, as I said earlier, to meet the 1998 deadline. Wednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2533 This is important, because there is a great number of opportunities for food processors, not only in exports to New Zealand-which are already very important to us-but, furthermore, in exports to other APEC countries. These opportunities will best be resolved when we can maintain our clean and green image through the successful operation of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. This bill allows the operation of that authority to be enhanced. I am pleased to support it. the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill. The bill amends the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991 to overcome operational limitations within the current principal act. The proposed amendments to the bill will enable the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to better plan, manage and prioritise its workload. The background to this bill is that the principal act amended by this bill was originally the National Food Authority Act 1991. The main goal of the authority is to provide a national focus within Australia for cooperation between governments, industry and the community in developing a safe and wholesome food supply. It is that topic that I wish to address, because one of the most important things for Australia is that it has enjoyed a very strong reputation overseas for clean, wholesome food products. It indicates how important it is, not only in our relationship with New Zealand but also-as the member for Wakefield ( Mr Andrew) mentioned-with our near Asian neighbours, and the wonderful opportunities that that provides for Australia to provide food to what we now term 'the supermarket to Asia'. I was delighted to hear recently of the move by the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) to create the Supermarket to Asia Council. The Australian food industry is one with tremendous potential to generate wealth, jobs and exports for Australians. It is one of the largest sectors of the Australian economy, with retail sales and exports valued at $64 billion. Exports of food in 1995-96 were $15 billion, with approximately 40 per cent of these exports going to Asia. The industry's potential for further growth is considerable because of the natural production advantages in Australia and its proximity to rapidly growing markets for food in Asia. This Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill ensures that both Australia and New Zealand reach agreement on joint food standards. It is imperative that New Zealand and Australia are in a position to present a united force to the Asian opportunities which are currently available. The diets of Asians are becoming more westernised, and this is creating new opportunities for the export of food products like meat-and I relate that to my own electorate where we produce beef, lamb and pork-dairy products, horticulture and grains, as well as a number of other very important primary products and foods which are suitable for inclusion in the strategy that the Supermarket to Asia Council is embarking on. The Supermarket to Asia Council was established by the Prime Minister and, without having the bill in place that we are dealing with in this House, we cannot ensure that food standards and consumer information on the ingredients in those foods are compatible between Australia and New Zealand. We need to ensure that, if Asian customers are looking at a supplier from within the Australia-New Zealand providers who are emerging in the marketplace and they are looking for food products, obviously they are going to be looking for the standard of quality, ingredients and information that is provided between those two countries to be compatible and
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Reid (Bendigo) (12.21 P.m.)
theText: I am pleased to have the opportunity to comment on2534 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 for there to be closer cooperation between Australia and New Zealand to harmonise those things. That is very important. Under the terms of this legislation, I am delighted to see that we are, in fact, bringing Australia and New Zealand much closer together in the standards that they provide, particularly on their consumer information on the ingredients. This is a complaint that a lot of members, I am sure, would receive in their electorate offices from time to time. People ask what the ingredients are in a lot of the products on the supermarket shelves, and there is no doubt that people who visit a supermarket these days have a pretty close look at the labels to make sure that they know what the ingredients are. It is important because of our close economic relationship with New Zealand that those standards are harmonised and, in fact, that there is close cooperation between the two countries. The proposed amendments will enable the authority to complete the major task of a three year standards review work program. Support and agreement to this program will set priorities for a food standards review and will involve negotiations with the food industry. I think that this is important because I just heard my colleague, the honourable member for Wakefield, who obviously had some discussions with the Food Industry Council of Australia. They have written to me also on this matter. They were concerned about the charges and I just arrived in the chamber in time to hear the honourable member for Wakefield address that question. I know the minister has made a note of that and, no doubt, will respond in the latter part of this debate. I have not had the opportunity of meeting with them but I am sure that those concerns of the Food Industry Council of Australia will be allayed by the minister. But it is important that we have full negotiation and consultation with the food industry, the states and the territories, and New Zealand in the implementation of this bill. I will leave my remarks at that point. I welcome the bill and support the initiative to bring both New Zealand and Australia much closer together. We already enjoy closer cooperation under the economic cooperation which we have between New Zealand and Australia and I welcome this further move. amends the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act to implement provisions which will enable the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to focus its resources on issues which are of critical importance to both countries. They include: the development, establishment and management of the Australia-New Zealand food standards code; the development and implementation of the new hygiene standards for food processing, manufacturing and handling, and the development of improved and consistent national arrangements for surveillance and compliance. This bill will enhance the authority's ability to undertake these important tasks. It is important that we maintain set standards and that, as a nation that closely competes with New Zealand in a lot of these areas, particularly as far as fresh food is concerned, we maintain close links as far as common standards are concerned. I certainly would like to add my support to the amending bill, the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill, in that regard. It is important that we maintain that close liaison with New Zealand and maintain a high level of standards in this area. I am certainly happy to support the bill and I commend it to the House. in the preface, the main purpose of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill 1996 is to allow the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to appropriately manage its
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Vaile (Lyne) (12.28 P.m.)
theText: I will be fairly brief in my support of this bill. The bill
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs Moylan (Pearce
theText: Minister for Family Services) (12.30 p.m.)-in reply-As is statedWednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITfEE 2535 workload. I know that there have been many compliments paid to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority by colleagues this morning for the work that it does but, as with any authority, from time to time things change and it needs to adjust its practices. It is important for us to have a look at the underlying reasons why we need to address some of the pressures on management and the growing workload on this authority. It is enormously important that Australia's food standards are dealt with in a timely manner so that we can continue to have public confidence and good public health practice in this country. We also cannot overlook the fact that the enhancement of the industry's ability to compete domestically and internationally has a very important economic purpose. We have also heard today from my colleagues just how important the food industry is in Australia and, indeed, it is an industry that is worth $40 billion. The current act requires the authority to assess, within a 12-month time frame, all applications made to it to vary the food standards code. This means that applications have first call on the authority resources regardless of their relative importance or their priority in the whole scheme of things. In practice, this has meant that resources have been diverted from the more important tasks, such as the review of food standards and the development of a joint Australia New Zealand food standard code, in order to deal with the sheer volume of applications that come in. The impact of the new bill will be to enable the authority, firstly, to allocate its resources to an agreed work plan that incorporates public health and industry and, of course, consumer priorities. It is immensely important, as I said, that we have public confidence in the system that we have in place. The second part of the legislation enables the authority to ensure a review of the entire food standard code and that it is completed in a timely manner, not interrupted by perhaps less important code changes. An important part of this legislation will allow for a charge for goods it produces, as well as for the existing power to charge for services and to waive fees, for example, for all work done in relation to the agreed work plan including, and in particular, public health priorities. The member for Dobell( Mr Lee) did raise some points that I would like to cover in the operation of this bill. The first point that he raised was the fact that the detail was not available. I am a little surprised at his comments because we all know in this place that it is hardly unusual for the main bill to come without those detailed principles in the first instance. But the detail will be scrutinised by the House and the Senate in the form of regulations to be introduced. The powers are not arbitrary; they are subject to disallowab1e instruments. The member for Dobell also sought details of priorities for setting out the work plan. I have to say that, again, I am a little surprised at the member's criticism here about not having detail because I understand that in the principal act the three key criteria are clearly set out. They go to issues of importance in terms of public health, consumer information which would prevent fraud and, of course, consistency within the industry and the elements of fair trading. So the three main priorities, or criteria if you like, for work to be progressed are set out clearly in the principal act. In addition to that, we also have a priority for setting a work plan. The first phase of this process has already been advertised in the national press and consultations have commenced with the state and territory governments and with the New Zealand government. Consumers and industry will also be part of that process. The member for Dobell also stressed the 2536 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 importance of the food standards review. Given that they see this as an important priority, this bilI will ensure that the project can be progressed and it cannot progress in a timely manner without this bill being passed. The member for Dobell raised an issue about the level of antibiotic residues in food and I understand from the department that the food standard code does set limits on residues of antibiotics in foods, whether they be domestic or imported. We can always provide specific detail of that to the member for Dobell, should he wish for that information. The member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) also made some comments, not unlike those from the member for Dobell, about the detail that was necessary. As I said, that will come forward in the regulations. His other concern was about a letter received from the Australian Food Council, a peak industry body. I think it is fair to say that the main concern in that letter revolved around the charging practices and, as I have said, the detail of those practices will come forward in the regulations and be scrutinised by this House and, indeed, by the Senate. It is important to convey to the House that there has been considerable consultation with the industry and, in particular, with the Australian Food Council-as I understand it, as recently as earlier this month. The industry's difficulties have been discussed and wiII be put into context through the associated regulations that will come before the parliament. The concerns raised are important but they can be dealt with properly through the foreshadowed disallowable instruments. The bill ensures that we protect what is a critical program that is important in the interests of public health and public confidence in the system. It also assists our industry to enhance its ability to compete, both domestically and internationally. This bil1 will al10w the authority to work with industry, consumers, the states and territories, and New Zealand in addressing, as a high priority, the food standard changes. Icommend this bill to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Bil1-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. of business, I thought I might commend for the notice of al1 ministers, parliamentary secretaries and, indeed, shadow ministers, the desirability of sitting at the front bench. After all, they are still more than a sword's length apart and there are no long spears here. Consideration resumed from 26 February. Second Reading move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill is about removing legislative impediments to the implementation of reforms in the electricity industry. These reforms, together with the gas reforms agreed by the Council of Australian Governments in February 1994, have been estimated by the Industry Commission to lead to an increase in annual gross domestic product of $5.8 billion.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl)
theText: Before cal1ing the first speaker on our next item
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Miles (Braddon
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister) (12.39 p.m.)-IWednesday, 19 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2537 To do this, the bill will amend part IlIA of the Trade Practices Act 1974, the principal act. Part IlIA includes provisions whereby third parties can seek access to services provided by essential infrastructure facilities of national significance. These provisions are an important feature of Australia's national competition policy reforms. They promote competitive markets in order to improve efficiency and service delivery. The amendments to part IlIA will provide a legislative framework to support reforms in network industries where a co-regulatory approach, as an alternative to direct regulation, is being used to implement pro-competitive market structures. This approach, which is being pursued in the electricity industry, involves the development of a code of conduct by industry participants and governments, setting out market rules, including rules about third party access to network infrastructure. In order to implement the access provisions of the code, it is envisaged that network service providers will offer access undertakings to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, later referred to as the commission, under part IlIA, setting out obligations in relation to network access. These undertakings are enforced by the Federal Court, upon application by the commission. There are, however, a number of shortcomings with the principal act which would prevent the timely implementation of this approach to access regulation. Firstly, the principal act requires the commission to undertake multiple public consultation processes before such arrangements can be established: one in relation to the code, if the code requires authorisation under part VII of the principal act, and others in relation to the access undertakings of individual service providers. This unnecessary duplication of public consultation processes is an inefficient way of processing access undertakings in network industries, and runs the risk of unduly delaying progress towards more competitive infrastructure industries. Also, it may be difficult for the commission to assess whether separate access undertakings will achieve coherent industry-wide access arrangements. Secondly, the principal act requires an undertaking to set out a high level of detail about the terms and conditions of access. Accordingly, an undertaking cannot include a maximum price or a formula with factors which are reset from time to time. Inclusion of highly detailed terms and conditions about access may be undesirable and impractical in certain network industries, such as the electricity industry, where an industry-wide approach to access is to be adopted. Thirdly, the principal act does not enable an access provider to confer power on the commission to make decisions about access issues pursuant to an undertaking. For example, in the case of access to the national electricity grid, it is envisaged that undertakings will provide for the commission to make decisions which will affect the price for access, in accordance with criteria set out in the undertakings. The bill will address these shortcomings by setting out a process whereby the commission can accept industry access codes, following public consultation. Each access code would set out rules about access for the industry. Once the commission has accepted an access code, the commission can accept access undertakings in accordance with the code, without the need for further public consultation. This process allows for the development of coherent access arrangements through a single consultation process. Furthermore, the bill will relax the level of detail required in an access undertaking. The appropriate level of detail will be determined by the commission and access providers, on a case-by-case basis. 2538 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 19 March 1997 The bill will also enable access providers to confer power on the commission to make decisions in connection with access. The undertaking would set out how the commission is to make its decisions, along with other relevant ancillary matters. In this regard, an undertaking could confer on the commission a role that is similar to its role under part IIIA of the principal act in relation to declared services, should an access provider choose to give the commission such a role. In addition, the bill includes a provision to preserve the integrity of the competitive conduct rules and authorisation provisions of the principal act. The bill provides that the access provisions in the principal act will not affect the liability of the relevant parties for contraventions of the competitive conduct rules in the principal act. The cost to revenue of the proposed amendments is expected to be nil. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and I commend the bill to the House. Braddon( Mr Miles), as parliamentary secretary, has given in this place a very different second reading speech to that delivered by the late and lamented Brian Gibson in the Senate, when he was acting as parliamentary secretary to the Treasurer. best way to progress one's interests in the Howard government. The relevant point for this debate on the Trade Practices Amendment (Industry Access Codes) Bill is that the speech is very different because the government brought into the Senate amendments to its own bill, and they were subsequently carried by the Senate. The parliamentary secretary, the member for Braddon, did not mention that, but the essence of those amendments concerns the level of public -consultation in a determination by the ACCC for further undertakings on the access regime. The Australian Labor Party naturally supports the access regime; we introduced it in the Hilmer package of reforms some two years ago. Mr LA THAM-The member for Corangamite will find, in my case, that consistency is a virtue. I am speaking in favour of the competition reforms we introduced in government and which remain in the national interest. The principle is very sound. In the case of infrastructure characterised by monopoly or oligopoly features you should not need to own an electricity power station to retail electricity and you should not need to own a gas pipeline to retail gas. I would also argue that, in the petrol industry, you should not need to own and have tied access arrangements to a petroleum terminal to be an effective retailer in that particular industry. So the concept of downstream access makes sense. It allows a competitive retail, and even a competitive wholesale, market to be established in industries which are essentially vertically integrated and have monopoly and oligopoly characteristics. These are basically infrastructure industries. The bill brought into the Senate is something that we have no problem with. The idea of an industry-wide access code seems to make some sense. The problem the Labor Party has with the provision concerns the amendments that the government put to its own bill in the Senate. They are amendments which minimise the public consultation process. They allow the
